track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Julia Child and Gordon Ramsay
track.annotation: Who knew?! Mike Boettcher loves to cook! He once spent a day with Julia Child, and now dreams of cooking with Gordon Ramsay!

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Global Hot Spots
track.annotation: Boettcher believes that the War on Terrorism is here to stay, and that America needs to set the example for the rest of the world.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Making a Difference
track.annotation: By telling people's stories, Boettcher says, you can change people's lives and have an impact on history.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: International Reporting
track.annotation: How news from half the world away can affect us all.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Technology
track.annotation: During his career, Boettcher has seen technology change rapidly, and that has made reporting from remote areas faster and more efficient.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Carlos
track.annotation: Boettcher's son, Carlos, is following in his father's footsteps.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Reporting Style
track.annotation: Boettcher calls himself a "fireman."

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Journalists Spies?
track.annotation: Kidnapped in El Salvador, Boettcher was accused of being a spy for the CIA.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: OKC Bombing
track.annotation: Boettcher says terrorists don't wear uniforms, and they don't have a country. Their capital, he says, is hate.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Bombed, Shot, and Poisoned
track.annotation: Working in very dangerous conditions in various "hot spots" around the globe.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Meeting Fidel Castro
track.annotation: Watching CNN with Fidel Castro and Ted Turner.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Migrating to TV and CNN
track.annotation: Before moving to CNN, Mike spent part of his early career at KWTV in Oklahoma City.

track.title: Mike Boettcher
track.ov:subtitle: Getting Started in the News business
track.annotation: From a small radio station in Ponca City to a fledgling all-news network called CNN, Mike talks about his early days in the news business.

track.title: On The Record
track.ov:subtitle: Mike Boettcher
track.annotation:
Ponca City native, and University of Oklahoma graduate, Mike Boettcher, has spent more than thirty years as a news correspondent for CNN, ABC and NBC. He has reported on some of the biggest stories in the world, winning national Emmy and Peabody Awards.
Boettcher talks about his coverage of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the early days of Cable News Network and his life as an international reporter.
Boettcher is currently on a year-long reporting assignment with the U.S. Army's 101st Airborne Division in Afghanistan.

track.title: On The Record
track.ov:subtitle: Marvin Kalb
track.annotation:
Marvin Kalb is a James Clark Welling Presidential Fellow at The George Washington University, and the Edward R. Murrow Professor Emeritus at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. He is also a contributing news analyst for National Public Radio and Fox News Channel.
Kalb had a distinguished 30-year broadcast career, working for both CBS News and NBC News, where he served as Chief Diplomatic Correspondent, Moscow Bureau Chief, and moderator of Meet the Press. Among his many honors are two Peabody Awards, the DuPont Prize from Columbia University, the 2006 Fourth Estate Award from the National Press Club, and more than a half-dozen Overseas Press Club awards.
Kalb is the founding director of the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics, and Public Policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Elie Wiesel
track.annotation: Kalb once asked Elie Wiesel if God was a good journalist.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: The Fairness Doctrine
track.annotation: The Fairness Doctrine was introduced in 1949 by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). It required broadcasters to report on controversial issues in an honest and fair manner. The doctrine was abolished by President Ronald Reagan in 1987.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Edward R. Murrow
track.annotation: Kalb was hired by CBS news icon, Edward R. Murrow.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Freedom
track.annotation: Kalb talks about his deep appreciation for the freedoms afforded to each of us as Americans.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Nixon's Enemies List
track.annotation: Kalb was on President Richard Nixon's "enemies list." He talks about how he made that infamous list, and also comments on the mistake he thinks President Obama may be making with Fox News.

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Partisan Politics and the Media
track.annotation: Can the media report on America's policy problems without being labeled as "liberal?"

track.title: Marvin Kalb
track.ov:subtitle: Citizen Journalists and the Mainstream Media
track.annotation: With the rise of "citizen journalists" who blog and tweet, Kalb believes the mainstream media and the American people need to "reconnect."
